results.title: Victoria Howlett: potter
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Victoria Howlett regards her pottery as a reflection of her personality, her travels and her various experiences. She finds inspiration for her work in nature and approaches her tasks very systematically.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: Chris Sanders: potter
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
This is a film about potter, Chris Sanders, working under the direction of an experienced master potter. After having had his own workshop for five years, Chris realised that he needed to learn more about the craft, and this could be best done under the guidance of a master potter. Both Chris and his master discuss this experience.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
This is a film about potter, Chris Sanders, working under the direction of an experienced master potter. After having had his own workshop for five years, Chris realised that he needed to learn more about the craft, and this could be best done under the guidance of a master potter. Both Chris and his master discuss this experience.
description_for_label:

This is a film about potter, Chris Sanders, working under the direction of an experienced master potter. After having had his own workshop for five years, Chris realised that he needed to learn more about the craft, and this could be best done under the guidance of a master potter. Both Chris and his master discuss this experience.

results.title: John Corbett: textile teacher
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme, Australia Council and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
John Corbett works at the Preston Institute, taking classes in weaving, tapestry, lace-making and other fibre work. He is a very enthusiastic teacher, although he has had no formal training he likes to bombard his students with new ideas from different people and cultures.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme, Australia Council and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: Joe Mcbain: blacksmith
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Joe McBain started as an apprentice blacksmith, in 1916, at a general blacksmith shop. These shops were involved in woodwork, mending farm equipment and shoeing horses. In this film, Joe talks about old blacksmithing methods.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: Vic Greenaway: production potter
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Vic Greenaway is an accomplished potter with his ceramic workshop set in the cournty where he works with two apprentices. Pottery for him is a lifetime work, a total commitment requiring all his energies and concentration.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: Tor Schwanck: gold and silversmith
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”
Metal-work has been in Tor Schwanck’s family since the 15th century. He is an artisan trained in all aspects of metal-work. Schwanck uses non-precious metals as well as gold and silver. All the designs are originals, and he tours, exhibits and receives commissions for his work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”

results.title: Stan King: book binder
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Stan King has been a bookbinder for forty-four years. Despite the mechanisation that has taken place, Stan believes that bookbinding is not finished as a craft and while there is a need for high quality books, there will be skilled craftsmen who will be able to produce them.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.

results.title: Ron and Mandi Heath: weavers
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
This film looks at the life style of Ron Heath, once a geologist and Mandi Heath who was a teacher, and their total commitment to their craft of weaving. They hope to make the farm on which they live self-sufficient and are continually experimenting with methods of weaving in their workshop which is in the nearby town.

results.title: Lilija Duks: weaver
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Lilija Duks is a weaver who came to Australia from Latvia. In this film she talks about both her own design work and the traditional Latvian weaving that she does.

results.title: Greg Wain: Potter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Although Greg Wain lives in the bush, his inspiration is drawn from large cities. Through his work Greg likes to demonstrate contradictions. He also enjoys the aesthetics of pottery, appreciating aspects such as colour, shape and the quality of the clay.
